text.p: Equitas, the company set up by Lloyds of London to reinsure the market's old liabilities, has quietly reached another landmark. Today, Equitas published its first set of accounts, giving a snapshot of its position when it was granted its licence in September last year.
The accounts appear to hold no big surprises and Equitas cautiously said it was on course to cover the insurance market's pre-1992 liabilities.
However, it faces a long journey over several decades and at this early stage in its odyssey, the auditors outlined several concerns.

First, there is the fundamental uncertainty overhanging the whole Equitas project. Nobody has ever carried out such a mammoth task before. Realistically, Equitas knows that it will only be able to shrug off this doubt if and when it largely completes its task some time next century.
Second, the auditors noted their concerns over the quality of some of the unaudited data underpinning the reserving assumptions. Equitas hopes to overcome this problem in time.
Finally, the outcome of litigation in the U.S. could have an effect on the size of some of the liabilities faced by Equitas.
Equitas always was intended to be a long-term project and it would have been surprising if at such an early stage the auditors had given the reinsurer unqualified approval.

Whatever happens, in the longer term Equitas is likely to remain the subject of much interest. If it fails, the implications will be far-reaching. If it succeeds, Lloyd's could find itself with a much sought-after asset.
